My English teacher said to me once, writing an essay and writing a novel are completely different things, to be good in one does not guarantee being good in the other. I personally find it hard to write fiction, it is much easier for me to write about something that's **real**.

WRITING.TITLE: The four stages of life
WRITING.TEXT:
1. You believe Santa Claus
2. You don't believe Santa Claus
3. You are Santa Claus
4. You look like Santa Claus

I have a little story here. I met an exchange student from Germany. We were talking about national anthems, and she said that they (or you guys, since you are German) rarely play their anthem, she doesn't like it cause it's the same song from the nationalistic era, and she thinks that everyone hates Germany, which is totally not true and I told her that. "The struggle is real," is what she said.
I came out very thoughtful after that conversation. It's sad and unfair in my opinion that you guys are still sometimes blamed for events that your great grandparents did. I for one have a very positive view of Germany, you guys owned up to what you did and changed, unlike the Japanese. I think you guys should be proud of your nation, in a good way. I know I am proud of mine, despite all the fuckups we had, and probably still going to for some years.
Story over, I hope I didn't offend you in any way. I have a very limited view on your country, since I only ever talked to a few Germans. But here's my two cents, take it in whatever way thou wilt.

WRITING.TITLE: [WP] You woke up in a place different from where you slept. "Beat the game to exit," the message said.
[WP] As long as you keep traveling, you will not age.

WRITING.TEXT:
I am listening to Dan carlin's podcast- blueprint for Armageddon. In it he talks about how Germany has changed the rules of war in WWI. Before, armies usually stayed in the tens of thousands men range. Armies are usually privately funded, and weapons are kept from civilians and the general public. Germany poured a whole nation's resources into war, conscripting over 2 million people, training civilians to fight, making all factories make ammunition and helmets, you get the idea.
Suddenly, life was cheap. Before, where generals have to be more conservative in spending men on assaults, now they can pour waves and waves of men to take down that one fort blocking the way. Correct me if I'm wrong, but I think that's how trench warfare started.
Before, men thought dying for your country in war was a great honor, something to look forward to. But that ideology changed when you are just one in thousands mowed down by a machine gun trying to overrun that Belgian fort blocking your way to France.
"What will I die for?" Soldiers wondered. "Am I just a replaceable pawn sacrificed on a giant Chessboard?" And they are not wrong.
Napoleon was the first to utilize an entire nation for war. But it was really the start of WWI that changed soldiers opinion on war. Before going into WWI, many countries still held on to war concepts from the 1800s. The French army had *red pants!* Some armies don't have helmets, others are missing boots, and the French still thought charging with your bayonet is fashionable. Well, they had to scrap all that after WWI.

Choose what is right, not what is easy. Its not really easy to define a brave choice, as everyones idea of brave is different. I think the first sentence sums it up well enough. If the path you want to follow is disapproved by many people, and you chose it, you are either brave.... or stupid. The line is thin, it depends on whether you succeeded or not *in the end*. Bill gates dropped out of university to start a business, and he became rich. Thousands followed in his footsteps, and failed. Are they crazy? Maybe, and maybe not. Who knows. Whats my point here? I dunno, chose carefully.
